MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: Video status conference held on 3/24/21. The next status conference will be held on 4/5/21 at 2:00pm CST. Prior to that time, the parties will provide to the Court, a schedule for the completion of the present phase of discovery. They will also, provide a schedule for the completion of all fact discovery. Fact discovery will include depositions as well as the production of documents. A schedule will also be provided for expert discovery, if any is contemplated by either party. It was reported today by counsel that discovery is "moving along well." For the video status conference set for 4/5/21 at 2:00pm CST, members of the public and media will be able to call in to listen to this hearing and should call 571-353-2300, then enter 094859009. Persons granted remote access to proceedings are reminded of the general prohibition against photographing, recording, and rebroadcasting of court proceedings. Violation of these prohibitions may result in sanctions, including removal of court issued media credentials, restricted entry to future hearings, denial of entry to future hearings, or any other sanctions. Mailed notice (yt) (Entered: 03/24/2021)

NOTICE TO THE PARTIES - The Court is participating in the Mandatory Initial Discovery Pilot (MIDP). The key features and deadlines are set forth in this Notice which includes a link to the (MIDP) Standing Order and a Checklist for use by the parties. In cases subject to the pilot, all parties must respond to the mandatory initial discovery requests set forth in the Standing Order before initiating any further discovery in this case. Please note: The discovery obligations in the Standing Order supersede the disclosures required by Rule 26(a)(1). Any party seeking affirmative relief must serve a copy of the following documents (Notice of Mandatory Initial Discovery and the Standing Order) on each new party when the Complaint, Counterclaim, Crossclaim, or Third-Party Complaint is served. MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: Status hearing held and continued to 12/16/20190 at 8:30 am. Initial discovery shall continue to be limited to the 135 properties previously identified, not to the much larger number again somewhat obliquely requested by the plaintiff. Based on representations made by defendants' counsel, loan agreements and regulatory agreements for the 135 properties are readily available and shall be turned over by 1/31/2020. The remaining discovery on the 135 properties discussed in the City's 11/27/19 report to the court 69 shall, as previously ordered, be on a rolling basis and must be completed by 6/30/2020, the date the City's counsel informed the court today she believed discovery could be completed. Despite intimations from counsel for the plaintiff, that is more than a reasonable amount of time in which to complete discovery. Counsel for the plaintiff are permitted, although not required, to take the depositions of those who submitted an affidavit/declaration in support of the City's Status Report relating to discovery. 68 . See, e.g. FTC v. Advocate Health Care Network, 162 F.Supp.3d 666, 671 (N.D. Ill. 2016); Tellabs v. Fujitsu, 283 F.R.D. 374 (N.D.Ill. 2012). Compare Schmidt v. Astrue, 496 F.3d 833, 842 (7th Cir. 2007). Should the plaintiff decide to take one or more such depositions, the subject matter is limited to the declarations in the case. Counsel are urged to call chambers at 312-435-5601 if any issues arise during any depositions. Counsel shall continue to file a written status report with declarations three business days before each status hearing with a copy delivered to chambers pursuant to Local Rule 5.2(f). The reports should focus not only on the difficulties claimed to prevent discovery, but on what discovery is next and when it will be made. Mailed notice (jms, ) (Entered: 12/02/2019)

MINUTE entry before the Honorable Robert M. Dow, Jr: Upon review of the status reports [114, 115] filed on 5/29/2020 and in view of the ongoing effects of all litigation as a result of the current global health crisis, the Court has come to the conclusion that any attempt to regulate the scope of discovery based on the Court's ruling more than a year ago denying Defendant's motion to dismiss would not assist the parties in moving the case forward at this time. The document that embodies the Court's ruling speaks for itself and any guidance that this Court gave the counsel almost a year ago surely is stale by now given the status hearings before Judge Cole and the unfortunate delays in the progress of this and other litigation as a consequence of the pandemic. Moreover, Magistrate Judge Cole has decades of experience managing complex discovery and resolving disputes over the pace and direction of document production, depositions, and every other aspect of litigation. He will be well positioned to give the parties the time and energy needed to help reactivate discovery in this case as counsel are able to resume whatever litigation activities they can consistent with social distancing and other restrictions on access to their workplaces and to third parties who may have information related to this litigation. For these reasons, the motion to clarify 79 is denied as moot and as superseded by subsequent events. Mailed notice (cdh, ) (Entered: 05/31/2020)

MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: Video Status conference held on 4/5/21. The City has filed a Status Report 170 in which it recounts its efforts to produce certain executed loan and regulatory agreements related to properties previously identified by the plaintiff. The City had been ordered to produce in the first wave of discovery some 100 properties on each of five specified dates. It has now done so. The City's final production of executed loan and regulatory agreements was made on 3/21/21 for the remaining 54 properties. Thus, the initial wave of discovery required by the City has now been completed, and the City's most recent Status Report details the effort required to meet the initial deadline. Thus, the City's most recent Status Report states that its "review of all non-publicly available Finance Division sources that may contain executed loan and regulatory agreements is complete, and all available executed loan and regulatory agreements related to the properties listed in Exhibit A to the Status Report have been produced." [170 at 2]. Given the completion of this first phase of discovery, the parties have submitted a Joint Proposed Discovery Schedule. 171 . That Joint Schedule is adopted and discovery shall be in accord with the following jointly agreed upon dates: All fact discovery, except development inspections, shall be completed by 3/1/22; completion of all development inspections by 7/1/22; plaintiff's expert disclosures by 8/1/22; Defendant's response expert disclosures by 10/1/22; close of oral expert discovery by 12/1/22. The next video status conference is set for 5/3/21 at 2:00pm CST. Members of the public and media will be able to call in to listen to this hearing and should call 571-353-2300, then enter 094859009. MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: This case is now 4 years and 4 months old. Despite prior orders in this case, especially dkt# 246, the parties have now filed a joint motion to again, amend a discovery schedule, while they acknowledge they did not anticipate requesting a further extension, "intervening staffing and family related health issuesand the need to continue to work collaboratively to set deadlinesin order to complete the final outstanding discovery items, has required the parties to jointly move for this short amendment." [248, para. 1]. See also [248, para. 5]. The motion also refers to "one of counsel's serious family health issues." [248, para.6]. In effect, the motion asks for a two month extension of the expert discovery schedule from 3/20/23 to 5/8/23, to that extent the motion is granted. The motion also seeks in essence, an extension of the fact discovery schedule from 8/1/22 to 11/28/22. The motion is granted. However, the parties should be under no misapprehension that THERE WILL BE NO FURTHER EXTENSIONS OF EITHER THE FACT DISCOVERY SCHEDULE OR EXPERT DISCOVERY SCHEDULE beyond the dates set forth in this Order. By the close of the period envisioned in this Order, the case will be almost 5 years old. At the risk of being repetitive, there will be no further extensions of this Order. See Judge Seeger's emphatic denial in 1:18-cv-03275 Boyd v. Pfister et al, "The Court meant what it said when it ordered that "this extension is the last."" The schedule set by this Order includes not only depositions but completion of development inspections. Emailed notice (yt) (Entered: 09/23/2022)

ANNUAL REMINDER: Pursuant to Local Rule 3.2 (Notification of Affiliates), any nongovernmental party, other than an individual or sole proprietorship, must file a statement identifying all its affiliates known to the party after diligent review or, if the party has identified no affiliates, then a statement reflecting that fact must be filed. An affiliate is defined as follows: any entity or individual owning, directly or indirectly (through ownership of one or more other entities), 5% or more of a party. The statement is to be electronically filed as a PDF in conjunction with entering the affiliates in CM/ECF as prompted. MEMORANDUM Opinion and Order signed by the Honorable Edmond E. Chang on 9/30/2024: For the reasons explained in the Opinion, the City's motion  307  for summary judgment is denied. The Court orders the parties to engage in settlement negotiation s. If negotiations stall or falter, then the Court will set a trial schedule. During pretrial litigation, the Court will ask the parties to address (among other things) whether the Court is bound for purposes of injunctive relief by any jury decision  on liability; and what the damages presentation at trial would entail. MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: Status hearing held and continued by agreement to 11/12/2019 at 08:30 AM. Certain out of town counsel, for the plaintiff, participated by phone. In discussions with counsel for both sides, it was their view that given the nature of the particular case, the provisions of the MIDP were not appropriate to effectively and expeditiously govern discovery here, and it was requested by all counsel that the MIDP not apply in this case. That request was granted, and discovery will proceed under the usual Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The parties initially shall engage in formal discovery regarding the 139 properties discussed in court today. Counsel shall submit a Joint Proposed Discovery Schedule by 10/9/2019. A few preliminary observations may be in order. [P]rotracted discovery, [is] the bane of modern litigation. Rossetto v. Pabst Brewing Co., Inc., 217 F.3d 539, 542 (7th Cir.2000). The undeniable fact is that under the realities of modern litigation[,] [p]re-trial discovery has become a monster on the loose.... Pre-trial proceedings have become more costly and important than trials themselves. A.H. Robins Co. v. Piccinin, 788 F.2d 994, 1013 (4th Cir. 1986). Thus, it is perhaps more imperative today than ever before that parties engage in discovery in good faith, without gamesmanship, In re Sulfuric Acid Antitrust Litigation 231 F.R.D. 331, 342 (N.D.Ill. 2005), and to cooperate with and facilitate forthright discovery. Johnson v. J.B. Hunt Transport, Inc., 280 F.3d 1125, 1132 (7th Cir.2002). See also Mills v. East Gulf Coal Preparation Co., LLC, 259 F.R.D. 118, 130 (S.D.W.Va. 2009). Accordingly, parties must respond with specificity to discovery requests, including by making particularized objections. Hall v. Sullivan, 231 F.R.D. 468, 474 (D.Md.2005). General or boilerplate objections to discovery requests are invalid. BankDirect Capital Finance LLC v. Capital Premium Financing, Inc., 2017 WL 5890923, *2 (N.D.Ill. 2017). This is not to suggest that any of these cautions will not be observed in this case. But given the importance of the case and the inevitable complexity of the discovery that is to follow, it is certainly not inappropriate to share with counsel some of the consistent views of judges throughout the country. See also Frank Easterbrook, Discovery As Abuse, 69 B.U.L.Rev. 635 (1989). Counsel are reminded of Local Rule 16.1(4) requiring that discovery be completed before the discovery closing date. If any issues arise during depositions, counsel are urged to call chambers at 312-435-5601.Mailed notice (jms, ) (Entered: 09/25/2019)

MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: On September 25, 2019, the parties were ordered to submit a Joint Proposed Discovery Order by October 9, 2019. [Dkt. # 54]. They asked for, and received a one-day extension of that deadline. However, a joint discovery Order was not forthcoming, despite its title. Apparently the parties could not agree on a schedule. Instead, two versions of a discovery schedule were submitted: one by the plaintiff and one by the defendant. The plaintiff's version sought one year of fact discovery and an additional three months of expert discovery. Under this timetable, all discovery is to end on 1/4/21. The Defendant, however, has proposed a different schedule. It wants two years for all discovery [Dkt. # 58] which would end on 10/8/21. In essence, the joint schedule is that in name only. This case was filed on May 13, 2018. On June 4, 2018, defendant asked for, and received, an extension of time in which to file a motion to dismiss and a stay of discovery until that motion was ruled on. [Dkt. # 14, 30]. The defendant's motion to dismiss was denied on March 29, 2018 [Dkt. #35] and, at the next status hearing on April 18, 2019, Judge Dow ordered that discovery proceed "on a rolling basis as expeditiously as possible." [Dkt. # 38](Emphasis supplied). Given what has already gone on, with a long break from discovery at the defendant's behest and Judge Dow's understandable and perfectly proper desire that lost time be made up for, the plaintiff's shorter schedule is more appropriate and will be adopted. Mindful of what the instant case involves, care must be taken not to be consumed by excessive and needless demands for discovery, which are "the bane of modern litigation." Rossetto v. Pabst Brewing Co., Inc., 217 F.3d 539, 542 (7th Cir.2000). See generally Frank H. Easterbrook, "Discovery as Abuse," 69 B.U. L.Rev. 635, 639 (1989). The public interest in the prompt and efficient resolution of legal disputes cannot and should not be ignored. See Fort Howard Paper Co. v. Standard Havens, Inc., 901 F.2d 1373, 1380 (7th Cir. 1990); Weingarten Realty Investors v. Miller, 661 F.3d 904, 913 (5th Cir.2011); Gray v. Schaub, 182 F.3d 921 (7th Cir.1999). Experience, which has a role to play in all cases, United States v Montoya De Hernandez, 473 U.S. 531, 542 (1985), teaches that the farther in the future a deadline looms, the less seems to be done in the time allowed. If things are not done until the last minute, as is unfortunately so often the case in the law, Gilliam v. Verizon Pennsylvania, Inc., 2014 WL 901296, at *4 (W.D. Pa. 2014), then it is better that the last minute comes earlier rather than later. Accordingly, the plaintiff's schedule is adopted. Any requests for extensions must comply with Fed.R.Civ.P. 6(b). The defendant's position that the length of 30(b)(6) depositions be determined on an as needed basis is adopted. The duration of depositions is defined by the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, which govern the discovery in the case absent a showing of some reason why the amount of time provided in the Rules should not be adhered to. Of course, counsel can agree among themselves to vary the prescribed time limits.Mailed notice (jms, ) (Entered: 10/17/2019)

MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: Telephonic status conference held on 6/3/20. Counsel agreed that discovery is not yet complete for the 135 properties to which discovery was initially limited, and that in light of the various impediments that continue despite everyone's best efforts, discovery as to these properties will not be completed before the expiration of three more months. This is not to say that once discovery in this limited regard has been completed, fact discovery will be completed. The parties have taken diametrically opposed positions on this issue, with the plaintiff insisting that the 135 properties would only constitute the first phase of what they insist will require discovery far beyond that limited to these properties. The city has a very different view. The extent of fact discovery is a matter to be determined at an appropriate time in the future. The next written status report is due on 7/2/20. Counsel should contact the Court should any difficulties arise once depositions have begun. I can be reached by a call to my courtroom deputy, Yulonda Thomas, at 312-408-5178, and she will arrange for me to participate in the phone call. MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: Telephone conference held with lawyers for the parties. Previously, discovery had been limited to 135 properties, the identity of which was determined by the parties. It was my view that discovery should proceed in segments and should not deal with the 800 or so properties that might be included in those properties adverted to in the Complaint. In my discussion with counsel today it became clear that as to logistical difficulties, largely the result of the coronavirus pandemic, precluding the completion of discovery as to the initial 135 properties and that an extension of that initial phase of discovery was necessary. Accordingly, a three month extension to 11/16/20 is necessary. The time for completion of discovery as to the initial 135 properties is now 11/16/20. I was told today that an examination of the "loan and regulatory agreements" pertaining to the initial 135 properties disclosed that a certain number of properties were not properly in the case as outlined in the Complaint. 1 . See also plaintiff's proposal on "next steps" for discovery. 124 . It seemed to me that an examination of the loan and regulatory agreements pertaining to the remaining several hundred properties potentially involved in this case would be productive as an initial matter and would help to pare the case down even further than originally envisioned by the plaintiff. Accordingly, discovery as to those properties other than the initial 135 should proceed broader discovery. Indeed, counsel on both sides thought it "likely" that such an examination would enable the parties to ascertain what should properly be included in the Complaint. I rejected the City's contention that this limited discovery should await the completion of discovery relating to the initial 135 properties. Accordingly, production of the loan and regulatory documents relating to the balance of the several hundred properties potentially involved in this case shall begin immediately. A closing date for discovery relating to the properties beyond the initial 135 shall be set at a future date. The court wishes to express its thanks to counsel for both sides for their input and assistance in this matter and for the proposed "next steps" for discovery. The next telephone status is set for 9/9/20 at 10:00am, and counsel should call (888) 684-8852, access code 5618926#. NOTICE of Motion by Jennifer Irene Klar for presentment of motion to enforce, 136 before Honorable Jeffrey Cole on 10/13/2020 at 11:30 AM. (Klar, Jennifer) (Entered: 10/07/2020)

MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: The Plaintiff has filed a Motion to Compel 136 the Defendant to comply with not one, but two previous Orders. [126, 133]. I note that we have been down this road before with the Defendant, with disappointing and unsatisfactory results, as recently as the status hearing on September 21st. In the two months since the first of those two Orders, the Defendant has managed to produce loan agreements for just 15 of the more than 600 developments potentially involved in this case. The excuse offered for this unsatisfactory and minimal compliance is the Pandemic. Everyone has been affected by the Pandemic, not just the City of Chicago and its lawyers. But not everyone has failed in their discovery responsibilities, and none to the degree the Defendant has done here. Counsel and their clients do not own the discovery schedule. See Motorola Sols., Inc. v. Hytera Commc'ns Corp., 365 F. Supp. 3d 916, 921 (N.D. Ill. 2019); United States v. Marder, 318 F.R.D. 186, 192 (S.D. Fla. 2016); Solis v. Washington, 2010 WL 1186184, at *3 (W.D. Wash. 2010). "'Managing the discovery process is the district court's business....'" Wanko v. Bd. of Trustees of Indiana Univ., 927 F.3d 966, 969 (7th Cir. 2019). As I said at the previous hearing on this same issue, the performance and excuses continually raised by the City are unacceptable. Another hearing on this matter is scheduled for October 13th, at which I am already inclined due to past history to enter Plaintiff's proposed Order that Defendant produce for 100 Developments each thirty (30) day period until Plaintiff's list is exhausted, either (1) Loan and Regulatory Agreements or (2) confirm that no such Agreements exist in either paper or electronic form. The utility of this solution as a device to quickly and efficiently streamline this case is not denied, nor could it be. But, the Defendant has not complied with prior Orders and instructions and importunings, and one wonders what hope there is that the Defendant will comply with Orders to comply with Orders. But courts are not helpless in the face of perpetual foot dragging in discovery. Consequently, Defendant shall file a written response to Plaintiff's Motion by October 12th. There will be no extensions of this date. The defendant has no one to blame but itself for the position it is in. In its Response, the defendant must address a point not raised by Plaintiff's Motion but one that is necessarily implicated by the City's continued evasion of basic and legitimate discovery requests: why a recommendation that a default judgment should not be entered against the City in the event of continued non-compliance with the discovery Orders entered by this court and which are intended to and will streamline the case. What the Seventh Circuit said in another context in which the City was the victim of discovery abuses, applies equally here where the City appears to be the abuser: "Enough is enough." Banos v. City of Chicago, 398 F.3d 889, 893 (7th Cir. 2005). See also Olcott v. Delaware Flood Co., 327 F.3d 1115, 1126 (10th Cir. 2003). Mailed notice (yt) (Entered: 10/08/2020)

MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: Video conference held on 10/19/20. On 10/8/20, I entered a lengthy Order, critical of what I perceived to be the City's continued noncompliance with Plaintiff's basic and legitimate discovery requests. 138 . The Order noted that the City had no one to blame but itself for the position it was in, and it referred to the consequences of a continued evasion of basic and legitimate discovery requests by the City. 138 . The defendants were ordered to respond to the Motion by 10/12/20. 138 . Almost immediately thereafter, the Defendant filed its eleventh Discovery Status Report. 139 . On October 12, 2020, four days after my Order, the City filed a Response to the Motion to Enforce Discovery Orders. 140 . A Declaration attached to the City's Response stated there are 715 boxes of Finance Division transactions containing hard copy documents at City Hall and are spread between the Finance Division suite and a separate storage area. [140 at page ID 1648]. The Declaration also stated that the Finance Division had copy documents, of which there were over 100 indices, also stored off site where, the Declaration did not say. In the Plaintiff's Reply 142 it contended that the parties have not reached any sort of agreement with respect to the City's search for electronic Loan and Regulatory Agreements. 142 . After considering the extensive argument by both sides in the recent video status conference regarding the City's claimed efforts to comply with prior Orders, I have concluded that the Motion to Enforce the court's August 7 and September 21 Discovery Orders 136 should be and is granted. Beginning on November 1, 2020 and every 30 days thereafter until the Plaintiff's list of developments potentially involved in this case has been completed, the City shall either 1) produce the required Loan and Regulatory Agreement (in whatever form they exist, if they exist) or explain their absence; or 2) confirm that no such Agreement exists in either paper or electronic form, so far as can be ascertained. As explained earlier, the presence of these documents will establish which entities should not be involved in the case at all and thus streamline the litigation. The representations regarding each of the Loan and Regulatory Agreements shall be made under oath and fully explain the circumstances should a particular Agreement not be producible. And they should confirm that no such Agreement exists in either paper or electronic form. In the event a Loan and Regulatory Agreement contemplated by this Order and the extended discussion during the October 20 status hearing not be producible, the City must explain under oath in a Declaration by an appropriate and competent witness why any particular Loan and Regulatory Agreement could not be produced. This court is hardly unsympathetic to contentions regarding the harm and dislocations caused by the pandemic as the October 8 Order demonstrates. See 138 and Smid v. Molex, 2020 WL 6132221 (N.D.Ill. 2020). However, merely and generally invoking the pandemic as a justification for noncompliance with the straightforward discovery requests in this case will not suffice. A final point regarding the mechanics of the review by the City required by this and earlier Orders: If the Law Department with its quite large number of attorneys representing the City finds it difficult to examine the several hundred boxes in order to determine whether a particular kind of document exists, the City should look beyond the Law Department to the two quite large Firms representing the City of Chicago. These firms have numerous offices throughout the country with many hundreds of lawyers. This is how discovery in major cases, indeed in cases far "larger" than this, is often conducted. In short, the excuses provided by the City for its failures to comply with reasonable discovery requests are not acceptable. Counsel should confer together by phone or in person and with sufficient regularity to be able to assure that reasonable and legitimate discovery requests will be honored and that discovery will proceed with sufficient efficiency that discovery may be completed in a reasonable time frame. The next video status conference is set for 11/30/20 at 9:30am. Mailed notice (yt) (Entered: 10/21/2020)

MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: The parties have filed a joint motion to amend the discovery schedule. 235 . The motion states that the parties are on track to meet the 8/1/22 fact discovery close date, except for the "development inspections," which will be, according to the motion to amend, completed by 10/17/22. The parties have asked that the expert discovery schedule be extended to 3/20/23 and they have provided a specific schedule for various occurrences in the motion. The joint motion 235 is granted. However, this is the final discovery extension that will be granted in this four year old case. Counsel are reminded of Local Rule 16.1, which requires that all discovery be completed, not merely scheduled, before the discovery close date. As provided in the Rule, discovery requested before the discovery closing date, but not scheduled for completion before that date, does not comply with the Rule. Finally, what the Fifth Circuit said in U.S. ex rel Taylor v. Hicks, 513 F.3d 228, 238 (5th Cir. 2008) should not be forgotten that "all good things, including discovery, must come to an end." Nothing in this Order is intended to detract in any way from the cooperative spirit that counsel have demonstrated thus far. That spirit of cooperation should not be overlooked and warrants special mention. ENTER ORDER. Emailed notice (yt) (Entered: 06/21/2022)

MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: Status conference and continued motion hearing held on 7/21/22. Fact discovery is scheduled to close in this 2018 case 1 on 8/1/22. 236 . On 7/13/22, counsel reported that discovery was proceeding without incident save for a possible issue of a potential 30(b)(6) deposition, requiring, according to the defendant, court approval. 240 . Counsel for the parties were unable to resolve the issue, and the plaintiff has moved to take a second 30(b)(6) deposition, which plaintiff says could span three days. 241 . Phrased differently, the motion asks that the duration of the deposition be expanded from the 7 hours allowed by Rule 30(d)(1) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure to 21 hours, which is 14 additional hours envisioned by the Rule. The defendant has objected to a second 30(b)(6) deposition of any duration. 243 . The plaintiff's motion states that in one of its status reports, it "expressly reserved" its right to notice additional 30(b)(6) topics at a later date. [241 at 3]. The plaintiff's motion observes that the defendant did not indicate it would object to further 30(b)(6) testimony. Of course, the defendant did not have to, and "inferences from silence are perilous." Posner, Cardozo: A Study In Reputation, 37 (1990). And in this case, in connection with this motion, no inference will be drawn. What is significant, though, is that nine months ago in October 2021 the plaintiff perceived a potential need for "further 30(b)(6) testimony," id. at 3, but did nothing until discovery was about to close, and only then sought a second Rule 30(b)(6) deposition, whose duration could be as much as 21 hours, if the plaintiff gets what it is seeking. I do not agree with the plaintiff's contention that leave to conduct a second deposition should "ordinarily" be granted, with the objecting party bearing the burden to show the deposition would be inconsistent with Rule 26. [241 at 5]. "[G]eneral propositions do not decide concrete cases." Lochner v. New York, 198 U.S. 45, 76 (1905)(Holmes, J., dissenting). See also Daubert v. Merrell Dow, 509 U.S. 579, 598 (1993)(Rehnquist, C.J., concurring in part and dissenting in part). The Rule governing approval or disapproval of requests for a second 30(b)(6) deposition ultimately is a function of the broad discretion invested in district courts overseeing discovery. Thus, there is no presumptive right answer when a second 30(b)(6) deposition is sought. Exercises of discretion do not presuppose or permit predetermined answers. Discretion means that the result need be only within a permissible range. Indeed, in matters of discretion, two decision-makers on virtually identical facts can arrive at opposite conclusions, both of which can constitute appropriate exercises of discretion. Compare United States v. Boyd, 55 F.3d 239 (7th Cir. 1995) with United States v. Williams, 81 F.3d 1434 (7th Cir. 1996). An abuse of discretion occurs when no reasonable person could take the view of the district court. Mejia v. Cook County, Ill., 650 F.3d 631, 635 (7th Cir. 2011); United States v. Banks, 546 F.3d 507, 508 (7th Cir. 2008); U.S. v. Re, 401 F.3d 828, 832 (7th Cir. 2005). Cf. United States v. Bullion, 466 F.3d 574, 577 (7th Cir. 2006)(Posner, J.)("The striking of a balance of uncertainties can rarely be deemed unreasonable...."). Indeed, "substantial discretion... ensures inconsistency." Johnson v. Daley, 339 F.3d 582, 593-94 (7th Cir. 2003). Following the conclusion of the writing of this Order, the plaintiff filed a status report 245 stating that in a conversation with the City, one of its lawyers had agreed to one additional day of 30(b)(6)deposition testimony [245 at 2, 5-6] and would agree to forego the additional two days the plaintiff had requested. According to the status report, the defendant rejected this offer, saying that "it would only remove its objection if plaintiff agreed to 3 1/2 hours of testimony. [245 at 2, 7]. The City responded a bit later that a 7 hour deposition was not acceptable, but it would remove its objection to an additional 30(b)(6) deposition if plaintiff would agree that the proposed deposition would only last 3 1/2 hours. That offer was declined and the parties had reached an impasse over whether the deposition should lasat 7 hours or 3 1/2 hours. Given the totality of circumstances as presented by the parties in 241, 243, 245, the plaintiff's motion is granted to the extent that it seeks to take a second Rule 30(b)(6) deposition. It is denied insofar as it seeks an additional 14 hours to depose the witness. Counsel on both sides of this case are reminded of the Fifth Circuit's admonition quoted in the Minute Order of 6/21/22 236 : "All good things including discovery must come to an end." U.S. ex rel Taylor v. Hicks, 513 F.3d 228, 238 (5th Cir. 2008). And they should keep in mind the wise admonition of Judge Moran: "Parties are entitled to a reasonable opportunity to investigate the facts-and no more." Vakharia v. Swedish Covenant Hosp., 1994 WL 75055, at *2 (N.D. Ill. 1994). With all deference, I am constrained to say that the controversy that involves whether a deposition should be 3 1/2 or 7 hours ill becomes our profession and helps explain Judge Posner's lament that "protracted discovery, [is] the bane of modern litigation." Rossetto v. Pabst Brewing Co., Inc., 217 F.3d 539, 542 (7th Cir.2000). The presently scheduled date for the close of fact discovery will stand. See also 236 . Emailed notice (yt) (Entered: 07/21/2022)

ANNUAL REMINDER: Pursuant to Local Rule 3.2 (Notification of Affiliates), any nongovernmental party, other than an individual or sole proprietorship, must file a statement identifying all its affiliates known to the party after diligent review or, if the party has identified no affiliates, then a statement reflecting that fact must be filed. An affiliate is defined as follows: any entity or individual owning, directly or indirectly (through ownership of one or more other entities), 5% or more of a party. The statement is to be electronically filed as a PDF in conjunction with entering the affiliates in CM/ECF as prompted. As a reminder to counsel, parties must supplement their statements of affiliates within thirty (30) days of any change in the information previously reported. This minute order is being issued to all counsel of record to remind counsel of their obligation to provide updated information as to additional affiliates if such updating is necessary. MINUTE entry before the Honorable Jeffrey Cole: Video status conference held. The issue of a possible settlement conference was again discussed. Unfortunately, while one side is willing to participate in a settlement conference, the other side wants to go forward with the case and has asked that in light of that position and discovery being closed, the referral be closed, and the case returned to Judge Chang. Under these circumstances, a forced settlement conference would serve no useful purpose. As the Seventh Circuit has quaintly put it, "If parties want to duke it out, that's their privilege." Goss Graphics Sys., Inc. v. Dev Indus., Inc., 267 F.3d 624, 627 (7th Cir. 2001). See also, Strandell v. Jackson County, Illinois, 838 F.2d 884,887 (7th Cir. 1988). Accordingly, all matters relating to the referral having been resolved, the referral is closed and the case returned to Judge Chang. Emailed notice (yt) (Entered: 07/12/2023)
